body:
You are using whiteList based metrics emission and default whiteList json file ([here](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/master/extensions-contrib/graphite-emitter/src/main/resources/defaultWhiteListMap.json))does not includes system metrics, hence metrics are not emitted. 

please add mapPath to eventConverter config as shown below,

`druid.emitter.graphite.eventConverter={"type":"whiteList", "namespacePrefix": "druid", "ignoreHostname":false, "ignoreServiceName":false,"mapPath":"<base absolute path>/druid_metric_whitelist.json"}`

Please find attached sample file which whitelists systems metrics.

[druid_metric_whitelist.json](https://github.com/druid-io/druid/files/1179985/druid_metric_whitelist.txt)

@drcrallen  I believe the message to be printed from https://github.com/druid-io/druid/blob/0.10.1/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/query/lookup/LookupReferencesManager.java#L366 which is a "warn" not "error" . Did you see "error" printed ? that would be unexpected.
in any case, i think its great to put it in release notes to avoid surprises. @drcrallen @jon-wei thanks.
üëç
@wywlds thanks can you please fill the CLA http://druid.io/community/cla.html

@gianm is `Task` interface not marked as extension point consciously or just missed ? I know at least one user who have written their own task.

We should also mark `LookupExtractorFactory` and `LookupExtractor` as extension points. I know of multiple QTL extensions which extend those.

Thanks @leventov. I will also ask other Druid members to share their thought on `Granularity` dimension b/c  its an important metric for our use-case but might not be true for everyone.
I also realized some of the dimension e.g `dimensionCardinality`, `addProcessedRows` are not emitted by default and could be emitted using custom extensions. My proposal is to control what to include/exclude via config rather than creating custom extensions. 

Config based approach could be:
1. Emit everything by default and a have blacklist config to determine dimensions to exclude.
2. Emit legacy metrics/dims by default and have a allowedList config  to determine new metric/dimensions to include. Release a list of new dimensions/metrics in the release note so that people can include new query metrics if they want to.

Config based approach has some advantages:
1. Users don't have to develop/maintain custom extensions to emit metrics  but they can still control what metrics they want.
2. Adding/removing query metrics will be easier.

@gianm @himanshug @cheddar @leventov  Suggestions ?
@gianm `ServletFilterHolder` and `PasswordProvider` too should be extension points.
In testing I found that the coordinator lookups APIs didn't have any authorization checks, latest commit attaches a ConfigResourceFilter to lookups APIs

@akashdw I considered "config" approach from the very beginning _instead of QueryMetrics_. In fact it was already questioned in the original PR, see https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3954#issuecomment-288829851, And I chosen `QueryMetrics` (call it "interface" approach) because "config" approach is not agile enough:

 - with "config" it's not possible to support the variety dimension and metric forms you may want to emit, e. g. different time resolution for time metrics (default now is milliseconds, and we in fact switched to nanoseconds).
 - you cannot skip computations, that are needed to produce some metrics and/or dimensions, that might be significant. See https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3954#issuecomment-288829851, `QueryMetrics.makeBitmapResultFactory()`
 - Dimensions and metrics are not independent, some may want to emit different set to dimensions for different metrics -- would be very cumbersome to setup a system allowing to config all possible combinations via properties.

So the complexity of the configs needed is very high, it's much harder to refactor them than code, while this system is still fundamentally much more restricted than "interface" approach.

> Users don't have to develop/maintain custom extensions to emit metrics but they can still control what metrics they want.

I understand that you don't want to do this but it's just what you need to do, if you want custom metrics and/or dimensions. It was clear when `QueryMetrics` was added and it's the foundation of it's mechanism, that I mentioned in this thread already: notification about changes via API change => your extension build breakage.

> Adding/removing query metrics will be easier.

How this statement is supported?

1. (config) Add a configuration, add documentation for it, add parsing of this configuration, add if-else or other ad-hoc logic to check this configuration throughout the code.

2. (interface) Add a method to QueryMetrics, add empty implementation in DefaultQueryMetrics, use the new method in already set up locations with a QueryMetrics object in hand (the entire point of #4184 and successors)

Why the first is easier?

> @gianm is Task interface not marked as extension point consciously or just missed ? I know at least one user who have written their own task.

I consciously didn't add Task because it's not listed on http://druid.io/docs/latest/development/modules.html. And with this PR, I was more trying to encode existing policy in annotations, rather than change the policy. That being said, I would +1 a proposal to make Task an extension point.

> We should also mark¬†LookupExtractorFactory¬†and¬†LookupExtractor¬†as extension points. I know of multiple QTL extensions which extend those.

Similar to Task, I left it out since it's not on http://druid.io/docs/latest/development/modules.html. In addition, Lookup APIs are explicitly described as "experimental" in the docs, so I think they shouldn't be annotated as stable. As long as they're experimental, users should be free to make extensions for lookups, but they shouldn't be guaranteed to keep working across upgrades.

> @gianm¬†ServletFilterHolder¬†and¬†PasswordProvider¬†too should be extension points.

Hmm, ServletFilterHolder is kind of borderline (it's not on http://druid.io/docs/latest/development/modules.html) but it's close enough to "Jersey resources" (which is) that I guess it makes sense to add. I'll do that.

PasswordProvider isn't on http://druid.io/docs/latest/development/modules.html but maybe it should be. I'll leave the annotation out for now.

What do people think about adding these as extension points?

- Task
- PasswordProvider

They make sense to me but since they aren't currently on the modules.md list I wanted to check for opinions. If we generally think they make sense then I can add them to modules.md and annotate them.
@gianm @himanshug it makes sense to me.
@b-slim Hi, I already filled the form when I created a pull-request last weekend.
Hi, David & Gian, I created a pr for this issue, #4607 .

> I'm thinking how BufferArrayGrouper can be used for merging partial aggregation results. One of the major problems for using BufferArrayGrouper for merge is the cardinality of the grouping key across segments cannot be acquired. One possible solution is computing the cardinality additionally while doing aggregation. It means, when performing per-segment query execution, hash values of the grouping key are collected using HyperLogLogCollector in the responseContext. When historicals or brokers merge partial aggregation results, they can use the collector to estimate the approximate cardinality. Even though there are some challenges like additional overhead for cardinality estimation (about additional 15% overhead in the benchmark) and approximate cardinality may cause buffer overflow if the actual cardinality is greater than the approximate one.

We could collect statistics like this ahead of time, and then there's minimal overhead during the queries. For example, we can collect HLLCs for string columns and min/max values for int columns. These could even be stored in the segments themselves.

> If this solution or any better idea is acceptable, BufferArrayGrouper should have the KeyType parameter to be used by SpillingGrouper or ConcurrentGrouper without huge code duplication. What do you think? @gianm

I'm not sure what you mean by this, could you elaborate a bit please?

@gianm `PasswordProvider` should definitely be an extension point, that was the primary reason for introducing it so that users can integrate Druid with their own internal secrets management systems effectively.
I don't feel so strongly about `Task` though, haven't seen a general need to extend it beyond one use case.

Here is sample query that group by field_1(Dimension) and order by Count(Metrics) and limits 10 results
Refer : [Druid limitSpec](http://druid.io/docs/latest/querying/limitspec.html ) more details,

`{"intervals":["start_date/end_date"],"granularity":"all","context":{"timeout":60000},"queryType":"groupBy","dataSource":"myDataSource","aggregations":[{"type":"count","name":"Count"}],"dimensions":["field_1","count"],"limitSpec":{"columns":[{"dimension":"count","direction":"ascending"},{"dimension":"field_1","direction":"ascending"}],"type":"default","limit":10}}`

> @gianm PasswordProvider should definitely be an extension point, that was the primary reason for introducing it so that users can integrate Druid with their own internal secrets management systems effectively.

I'll make PasswordProvider an extension point too.

> I don't feel so strongly about Task though, haven't seen a general need to extend it beyond one use case.

I'll leave Task as "internal" for now, but if there is some consensus that it's a good idea to make it a formal extension point, then I'm ok with changing it.

@himanshug @jihoonson @leventov I made the adjustments discussed, and also updated the modules.md doc to reflect what has been annotated (as well as provided some more "hints" for implementors).

Please let me know what you think, especially about the modules.md changes.
Also, at some places both in prod and test code, this PR changes constructs like `new DateTime().getMillis()` with `System.currentTimeMillis()`, should be OK but please review.

@leventov After this change, we're hitting a ClassNotFoundException: org.hyperic.jni.ArchNotSupportedException exception from the JvmMonitor class. It seems that in server-metrics 0.5.0, JvmMonitor has a dependency on Sigar which is not pulled into Druid because of the optional dependency.
Timeseries can only sort by time (hence the name). groupBy can group by time and sort by something else, which sounds like what you want.

> Changes in¬†druid-sql¬†module are special, I changed something but even not sure that it's right,¬†@gianm¬†could you please review those changes? Also, druid-sql uses GMT time zone on a few occasions instead of UTC,¬†@gianm¬†does that have a reason?

The druid-sql changes look ok to me. The code using GMT is doing that because it's creating an object that Calcite will use internally, and Calcite expects it to be in GMT (it will throw an exception if not).

After some experimenting, I can update regarding item 3, that on our Hadoop cluster (4 cc2.8xlarge servers) increasing the number of concurrent hadoop index tasks to 30 does not seem to make the jobs run slower. So, as I understand from this, each such individual task is running (mostly) sequentially. By increasing the number of concurrent jobs, we were able to reach the speed we wanted.

Any feedback on 1 / 2 will be appreciated

Thanks

Eran

> We could collect statistics like this ahead of time, and then there's minimal overhead during the queries. For example, we can collect HLLCs for string columns and min/max values for int columns. These could even be stored in the segments themselves.

Good point. I'll open new issues for storing more statistics in segments after finishing this pr.

> I'm not sure what you mean by this, could you elaborate a bit please?

There is a trade-off between type-specific grouper and code duplication. If a grouper is specialized for a specific type like BufferArrayGrouper is specialized for integers, the callers should also be specialized for the type which might increase duplicated codes. If BufferArrayGrouper is used inside SpillingGrouper or ConcurrentGrouper in the future, I guess there will be huge code duplication because SpillingGrouper and ConcurrentGrouper are designed to handle any key types.

This is what I'm concerened with so far. Now, I decided to make BufferArrayGrouper specialized because it can boost its performance by about 10%.
Druid does support running on UTC only.
@JLLNANA http://druid.io/docs/latest/operations/recommendations.html

Note that another option for implementation would be to have the keys fetched lazily instead of eagerly. Such a setup would allow for the file to change underneath.

Such a setup is both good and bad.
@gianm @jihoonson can you please finish the review ?
@niketh bounding the queueSize is available option for safety only , just in case if you didn't have enough jetty threads to handle requests before failing at the filter.

I added a couple more changes to this PR from a discussion with @gianm:

- Instead of wrapping all HttpClients created by HttpClientProvider with authentication credentials, code that uses HttpClient must explicitly escalate their client. This should help reduce instances where the HttpClient is unnecessarily escalated with internal system privileges.

- The PreResponseAuthorizationFilter originally errored out responses for requests that did not receive any authorization checks. However, some testing revealed that the response modification broke proxying behavior (e.g. OverlordProxyServlet on the coordinator). Since this feature was more intended to help developers catch authorization bugs, the latest commits now remove the response modification portion.

> There is a trade-off between type-specific grouper and code duplication. If a grouper is specialized for a specific type like BufferArrayGrouper is specialized for integers, the callers should also be specialized for the type which might increase duplicated codes. If BufferArrayGrouper is used inside SpillingGrouper or ConcurrentGrouper in the future, I guess there will be huge code duplication because SpillingGrouper and ConcurrentGrouper are designed to handle any key types.
>
> This is what I'm concerened with so far. Now, I decided to make BufferArrayGrouper specialized because it can boost its performance by about 10%.

Ah, I think that makes sense for now. We can revisit it if we ever need to wrap the array grouper inside spilling or concurrent. We could also do it without specializing them.
@leventov any further comments?
Great, thanks @gianm!

Should we backport this to 0.10.1?

It looks like the bugs were introduced in #3643 (0.10.0) so they're not new bugs in this version, but, they're pretty new overall. And some of them look kind of gnarly.

- The first and second mean that clusters with 1 MM (common in testing) will behave badly.
- The second means that any cluster with relatively low traffic in tasks could behave badly.
- The third could happen on any kind of cluster.
- The additional logging is nice.
Also related: #4576 could be used for numeric columns if min/max values were available.
While reading this I thought of another problem with blacklisting: #4620

(Major caveat, we do *not* have queries quite like this in production, so this is speculation)

Couple of things to note:

Your first name + last name is not really an identifier. You have some underlying information you are hiding (unique identifier) whose property is a first name and last name. Unless you really are trying to sum the purchase amounts of all people who have a first and a last name (and no other name of record) which happens to equal the tuple `("james", "smith")`, you might want to consider finding a way to store the underlying data with the events, and consider things like first and last name as metadata about the "real" event data (unique id) that needs to be handled either at ingestion time through ETL, or query time with QTL.

Lets look at the case where there's really a unique ID underneath, and you want information related to the unique ID.

For the total purchase amount, it becomes pretty straight forward. You simply sum the total purchase amount by the unique ID. This becomes more complex if you have something like "was on premium plan" or similar. In such a case the state of the "plan" is also related to the purchase item, and becomes much more complex to analyze. You should be able to look at a particular user ID, and look at the different plans each user ID was on, and do the purchase amounts that way if such a calculation is needed (or look at the different plans and look at the user IDs per plan).

If you want to do a state accumulation, you are going to have a very odd time in Druid due to the eventual consistency nature of the data store. But let's say for the sake of argument that its OK and you have some time to make sure the state is consistent. In such a scenario it should be possible to process a "sign_up" event as a 1 and a "deactivate" as a 4, then if you add them together by unique ID you should get 5. If you do not get 5 hopefully you get 1. If you don't get a 5 or a 1 then you hopefully have a 0 (never seen) or else have a problem (duplicate or error events). If you allow for repeat signups you can either have new user IDs or come up with something more complex.

State transitions (unknown --> signup --> inactive) are something that have been asked about before, but I don't know of any particular group that has attempted to solve it in Druid.

Committed a revision with somewhat more invasive behavioral changes to the following:
- Change the blacklist period to begin from when a task failure triggers the blacklisting and not after the last task on the worker completes
- If there are tasks running on a worker when it is blacklisted, if any of those tasks complete with SUCCESS the worker is removed from the blacklist
- A worker removed from the blacklist will have its consecutive failure counter reset and will not immediately be re-blacklisted on the next failure
- If a worker is removed from the cluster and this causes the number of blacklisted workers to exceed the max blacklist percentage, workers will be removed from the blacklist to bring us back below the maximum
- Overlord console now reports a `blacklistedUntil` timestamp for workers
@gianm maybe you have some ideas about this one? :)
@b-slim system timezone is widely used yet though, see #4611

thanks @dclim!

> Change the blacklist period to begin from when a task failure triggers the blacklisting and not after the last task on the worker completes

That sounds good to me.

> If there are tasks running on a worker when it is blacklisted, if any of those tasks complete with SUCCESS the worker is removed from the blacklist

I could go either way on this (either ignore the success, or treat it as un-blacklisting) but I'm good with the way you did it.

> A worker removed from the blacklist will have its consecutive failure counter reset and will not immediately be re-blacklisted on the next failure

This does seem better. Probably the best overall is to have some sort of decay of the counter but I don't think that's necessary for this patch.

> If a worker is removed from the cluster and this causes the number of blacklisted workers to exceed the max blacklist percentage, workers will be removed from the blacklist to bring us back below the maximum

Great.

> Overlord console now reports a¬†blacklistedUntil¬†timestamp for workers

Also very useful. I'm thinking it would also be useful to show the last few time(s) the worker was blacklisted, since due to the blacklist cleanup period, a worker that is legitimately bad would go in and out of blacklisting periodically. In this case the way you'd resolve it is that an operator (or the autoscaler) would notice that a node is getting blacklisted a lot, and remove it permanently or repair whatever is wrong with it. I also don't think this is necessary for this patch though.

Checkstyle failure looks legitimate.

```
/home/travis/build/druid-io/druid/indexing-service/src/test/java/io/druid/indexing/overlord/RemoteTaskRunnerTestUtils.java:222: error: [ClassCanBeStatic] Inner class is non-static but does not reference enclosing class
  public class TestableRemoteTaskRunner extends RemoteTaskRunner
```

we ingested data with Druid 0.9.2 using hadoop 2.7.2 and the error is gone now.
Not sure whether the bug was in Hadoop's BytesWritable.Comparator or in Druid's IndexGeneratorCombiner.
Not sure whether it needs to be investigated further or whether this is enough to close the ticket.

@leventov am not sure am getting your comments, currently as per https://github.com/druid-io/druid/issues/2619 we still highly recommend to run the JVM on UTC timezone otherwise bad things will happen, haven't looked at your PR yet but hope it fixes 2619
Probably fixes #2619

I wonder if we should change the direction of the conversation.  One sad thing that we ran into and only just found out is that we've always wanted to have metrics emitted that represent the number of rows scanned.  In looking into this, it looks like that has actually been implemented because there is a metric method added for that, but the actual code implementation isn't anywhere to be seen so we're not able to take advantage of the work someone else has already done.

So, maybe we need to discuss when we think a metric or dimension should be in the default, core set and when it shouldn't.  If we have that conversation, then the question becomes whether or not "granularity" should be a dimension included on all query metrics that have a granularity.

I tend to think that including granularity isn't a big deal (you will get a lot more cardinality from the id or the segment ids) and it provides a nice level of drill down that can help when trying to understand the performance profile.  What are your concerns with adding it to the core set of dimensions?

defaulting to DOUBLE means various UI clients that depend on segment metadata query would need to be upgraded before druid upgrades.
e.g. our ui sends segmentMetadata queries and suddenly started getting `DOUBLE` columns that it couldn't understand and started failing.

so, for 0.11.0, i would also agree for defaulting doubleXXX aggregators to old behavior of storing `FLOAT` columns and provide a way to opt-in to get them to store `DOUBLE` column.
@a2l007 https://github.com/metamx/server-metrics/pull/33 can you peek at that one? it should fix the problem.

@cheddar what do you think about adding a set of `QueryMetrics` impls to the core like "FullTopNQueryMetrics", "FullGroupByTopNQueryMetrics", etc., opposed to DefaultXxxQueryMetrics they emit everything for what method exist. Not that somebody want to use them as is, but they may serve as foundation for your private impls, which you may even derive from FullXxxQueryMetrics and just override a few methods with empty bodies.
@drcrallen once the server-metrics dependency is updated in Druid, it should fix it.
https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/4624

The problem with adding dimensions/metrics emitted by default, is not that it harms e. g. us (we already use our custom QueryMetrics query impls, so it's indifferent), but that it's almost impossible to take them away in the future. The amount of metrics emitted by default is like entropy, never goes down. The existing set of dimensions emitted by default is already bad, e. g. intervals, segment, id almost doesn't have any practical sense.

Making own QueryMetrics has a non-trivial upfront cost (about a man-day) but Yahoo as a big user of Druid will have to do it anyway, sooner or later. But after the setup is done, the support is very easy.

@yiguolei see #2426

IMO forceLimitPushDown should should throw an exception saying "cannot forceLimitPushDown with havingSpec" (or be ignored) if there is a having spec. To me, the purpose of forceLimitPushDown is to "make groupBy behave approximately like topN", which is useful. But if there is a havingSpec then I can't think of a situation where forceLimitPushDown makes sense and I think we should block it for users' own sanity.
Is this new behavior in 0.10.1? Wondering if it needs to be a 0.10.1 release blocker or not.

`resetOffsetAutomatically` only works if the next available offset in Kafka is greater than what the task is trying to fetch. In this case it seems like the next available offset would actually be less than what is being fetched. So you will need to reset the Supervisor manually, see "Reset Supervisor" here - http://druid.io/docs/latest/development/extensions-core/kafka-ingestion.html
This end point is available in 0.9.2 onwards
I'm not sure, we only started adding nodes after we upgraded to 0.10.1 and I don't really want to downgrade.

yes, I used manual reset but don't think that it is good approach to do things manually on each topic reset.
why cant it be reset automatically if current offset  is bigger than next available offset?

Hi @JingJunShen, you can do it by writing an extension, subclassing SqlOperatorConversion and calling SqlBindings.addOperatorConversion to register it.

Please be aware these are still evolving APIs and are not guaranteed to be stable from release to release. So your extension may need to be recompiled for each version of Druid that you want to use it with. As Druid SQL matures more the APIs will become stable.
Sure, I can take a look at that in a bit

Interesting question.

What did the btree implementation look like? Was it hooked into Druid at all or did you do it as a separate thing? Was it reading from mmapped something into java.lang.Strings, like Druid would?

What I remember from looking at profiles is that when reading dimension data, a big chunk of the time is spent decoding UTF8 into java.lang.String. It could be cached but is not by default (see `druid.processing.columnCache.sizeBytes`).

I was also considering that for some cases (like the Scan or Select queries) we could improve throughput by doing these operations in chunks. So we could read 1000 rows from a dimension column and then go and lookup all the names later. CPU cache behavior should be better, and also we may save some UTF-8 decodes if the 1000 rows have fewer than 1000 unique values. This can work even if the column-cache from `druid.processing.columnCache.sizeBytes` is disabled.

I think adding another (optional) section to Druid string columns is good if it's going to give a benefit. It should be optional so people that don't want it, don't need to store it.

Also wondering what you think about the chunk operation suggestion.

@jihoonson @gianm 

Added unit tests for the having/limit push down interaction

Very useful documentation!

If its Ok to state this here, some formulations are not 100% clear to me still:
- "When a set of segments are merged during indexing". In which situations would segments be merged? Only in a Merge Task or any hadoop index task or only in re-indexing tasks? Is it correct to assume that "indexing" is something that only happens during the ingestion of data, so it is not happening on broker/historical, right? To my understanding, "indexing" is the creation of an index which would happen only during the ingestion of data, but then again, in the query phase, segments get scanned and segments contain indexes and they get merged and there are merge buffers, so I was wondering whether "segment merging during indexing" only refers to the index creation in the ingestion phase or also something that happens during query processing? I think its the first but I'm insecure...
- "fuzzy parameter meant to account for the decompression and dictionary merging buffers"
Prior to this phrase, the documentation mentions "merge buffers" but I got the feeling that "dictionary merge buffers" are yet something else. If so, it would be great to get a brief explanation of what they are and where they come into play (historicals? / brokers? etc) 
- "Indexing workers and historical"
I've been working with Druid for 18 months now but I'm still insecure about the use of the term "Indexing" as the documentation as a whole _explains_ terms like overlord/middlemanager/peons/realtime nodes but then _uses_ terms like "indexing service" or "indexing workers" and I don't know what exactly how these notions connect. What exactly is meant by "Indexing workers" in this case? Does it mean Peons/Middlemanagers? Other documentation also sometimes talks of "indexing service" in which case I'm not sure if "indexing service" is the short form of "Kafka Indexing service" or if "indexing-service" == overlord+middlemanagers+peons or if Indexing service == realtime nodes... I do feel that I understand all concepts and moving parts of Druid, it's just the terminology itself that throws me. A reoccuring pattern is that I read about similar terms and don't know if they are synonymous or not. 
- Below the newly added documentation, there is a section that says
"Larger values allow for more aggregations in a single pass over the data while smaller values can require more passes depending on the query that is being executed"
How can I tell whether Druid is needing several passes over the data? To my understanding, in order to achieve top performance, Druid should be doing only a single pass over the data. Therefore, I would like to make the processsing buffers sufficiently large such that for all query scenarios that can occur on my particular cluster, all query processing would be done in a single-pass fashion. So how can I tell whether that is actually happening? Lets say I have a testsuite covering all query scenarios over my particular dataset. How can I measure how many passes Druid ends up taking given my current memory settings? There is a segment scan time metric and if it is too high, that might indicate several passes, but thats just a fuzzy measure. Is there a way to read off how many passes were taken? Is this being logged or emitted as a metric?

@gianm thanks for response.

 Actually I have done the profile and tuned the codes with the methods what you mentioned before. Yes, the profile shows that string decode and GenericIndex.get is the hot bottleneck. I ever fetched the dictionary string bytes directly out from the mapped ByteBuffer without decoding.This will send the pure bytes to the front end console.But no noticeable performance gains. Chunk operations also been tried. I first cached a batch of (row number --> dictionary idÔºâpairs,then batch looked up the dictionary values. The performance gains was also not noticeable.

I think the reason is that batched dictionary ids may cross different cpu cache blocks. To a high cardinality dimension column , looking up the dictionary value is a randomized seeking operation not sequential reading(I think sequential reading is the key point why metric columns perform so good , it will leverage the CPU prefetched data ,no cache switch ). The parquet project also adopts the dictionary encoding.But it divides the rows  into separate row groups --> chunks--> pages ,each page's column data size is CPU cache friendly by using dictionary encoding. But this method may not apply to Druid ,as Druid needs a global dictionary to a segment to do the filter operation(Of cause ,maybe we can have some other tricks to solve it .welcome to discuss that).

I do the exercises out of the Druid by using the jdbm3 project. One column a btree, using the mmap too . Once we got the filtered bitmap(meaning selected row numbers),we just need to browse the matched btree leaf nodes(notice that browse method,not get) . The underneath operation is sequential reading linked dimension values. If we add this additional storage format ,the option strategy is indeed need, as user will pay for the additional disk storage space.
Please fix the build failure.

@leventov Maybe it's not the best place to raise my question on processing threads configuration, but it's kind of related.

Currently, the number of processing threads are tied to the usage of directly memory. But I think it is not the correctly way.
As far as I know, only groupby v1 and topN query uses the reserved processing directly memory. The number of processing thread is limited due to the memory ls limited (like 16g or 32g per jvm).
In my druid cluster, most queries are timeseries and groupby v2 query, the cpu usage is very low but sometimes the scan pending is high which means there aren't enough processing threads and queries have to wait. If I increase the processing thread number, I have to allocate more directly memory even I don't actually need this part of memory due to I only use timeseries and groupby v2 query (more crazily, it is eagerly allocated when startup!).
I think we should un-tie the processing thread and direct memory and create a direct memory pool for queries who actually need it (like group by v1 and topN query). then we can manage direct memory more clearly and less waste.
is it fixed?

Thanks for the report @erikdubbelboer!

This is related to the LoadQueuePeon changes from https://github.com/druid-io/druid/pull/3736.

These logs would be generated every 50ms for each historical node that's currently loading segments.

I'm moving this issue to 0.11.0 since the related changes were introduced in 0.10.0 and the excessive logs, while troublesome, aren't a critical blocking failure.
